intro: Ichnanthus longispiculus, commonly known as the long-spined bladderwort, is a carnivorous plant native to freshwater habitats in North America. It possesses specialized bladder-like structures that trap small aquatic organisms, which it then digests for nutrients. The plant typically grows in shallow, still waters and has slender, branching stems covered in tiny, root-like structures. Its flowers are small and greenish-white, often clustered in dense inflorescences. Ichnanthus longispiculus plays a unique ecological role in its environment by contributing to nutrient cycling in aquatic ecosystems.
